subject: ARTS
text: ApracticeofKerala,itisconsidered one of the oldest forms of martial arts worldwide. Legend says that it originates from Parashurama, the great sage, who is deemed to have been the creator of Kerala. Recent researches connect it to the Sangam Period, 600-300 BCE. Developed as a self-defence mechanism, the training is based on the scientific marma knowledge of Ayurveda and has movement phrases which are based on animal stances and movements.

subject: ARTS
text: A martial arts practice from Manipur, the word means the ‘Art of Sword and Spear’. It harmonises the inner energies with outer actions, expressing various kinds of movements with rhythmic breath control. It is also ritualistic in practice. It is believed that all movements of the Meitei people have originated from Thang-Ta.

text: EXAMPLES OF INNOVATION

subject: ARTS
text: Many dance artists have experimented with their dance forms to tell contemporary stories and showcase current scenarios. You have learnt about two pioneers of the modern dance development in India in Grade 7. In continuation, there are many other dance practitioners and institutions that have been instrumental in developing choreographies using creative movements as well as using traditional dance vocabulary to depict stories of today through dance.

subject: ARTS
text: The following are a few among many such artists who have made significant contributions. Each of them has been honoured with the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award for creative choreography.

subject: ARTS
text: Try to practice one or two movements of the above martial arts with a visiting practitioner or under the guidance and inspection of a teacher from the QR code.

subject: ARTS
text: (Garenara Sharma expanded his horizons and carved a niche for himself in developing creative dance. One of the senior-most students of Uday Shankar, his many choreographies and dance dramas reflected socially relevant contemporary situations. He is known to create a healthy free dance movement for children, in which his efforts have shown substantial success with the institutionalisation of dance education. He produced over 40 original fabulous works, including notable productions like Kamayani (1970), Wolf-Boy (1977), Antim Adhyaya (1985), and Gandhi (2007). These works were acclaimed for their innovative themes and choreographic excellence.

subject: ARTS
text: Acharya Parvatikumar was a pioneering dance

subject: ARTS
text: choreographer for dance dramas like ‘Discovery

subject: ARTS
text: of India, Rhythm of Culture, and Dekh Teri Bambai’

subject: ARTS
text: where he seamlessly integrated various Indian dance

subject: ARTS
text: styles and showed contemporary concepts using

subject: ARTS
text: traditional dance forms, for example, creating a scene of the Dabbawalas taking deliveries around the city using kathak footwork, showing the chase between police and thief using the game of ‘hu-tu-tu’. On the traditional dance front, he was the only dance Guru to have researched and choreographed the Marathi compositions of Raja Sarfoji II of the Bhosale Dynasty in Bharatanatyam. He also bridged the gap between theory and practice by choreographing the dance text Abhinaya Darpanam into an audio-visual form.

subject: ARTS
text: Chandralekha was one of the earliest dancers who dramatically brought changes in traditional forms and synchronised various Indian dance, yoga and kalaripayattu with philosophy, and literature also. In her production Angika, she presented traditional Bharatanatyam vocabulary of dance based on the principles of Abhinaya Darpana and integrated Kalaripayattu with it. Lilavati was based on Bhaskacharya’s mathematics treatise which she choreographed in dance using numbers, nature and imagination. Prana was based on yoga and breath in dance. She has also worked with modern dancers and actors from the West in experimental productions. She has made films on dance and written on the subject. Among her films are The Myth of Woman (1976) and Hasta (1984).

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
text: a pioneering kathak dancer and choreographer who revolutionised the traditional solo format of kathak by introducing group choreography and contemporary themes. Going beyond the traditional repertoire, she asked, “Where do I go from here?”. Thus, her first groundbreaking choreography, Atah Kim, was born. Other creative dance productions were Dhabkar (Pulse), The Coat, Feathered Cloth (Hagoromo) among many others. Her dance choreographies integrated the abstract and narratives, often addressing contemporary themes.

text: A PRESENTATION OF DANCE aoe AND CHOREOGRAPHY oi

subject: ARTS
text: You are familiar with the Natyashdastra and the Abhinaya Darpanam now. In ancient times, when they were written, dance was usually called nrtta and nyitya or nartana, whereas dance-drama was called natya.

subject: ARTS
text: Have you ever wondered how dance originated?

subject: ARTS
text: If you refer to your Grade 6 Arts textbook (Theatre), you will recall an interesting story about the birth of the performing arts. Similarly, you will learn about the birth of dance from the Abhinaya Darpanam.

subject: ARTS
text: Brahma Deva, derived from all four Vedas, is said to have created the Natya Veda, often referred to as called the fifth Veda.

subject: ARTS
text: Brahma Deva gave Natya Veda to a Rishi, Bharata Muni, who studied and mastered all three aspects of nytta, nritya and natya.

subject: ARTS
text: CiGEDANCENNGG also}

subject: ARTS
text: Bharata Muni along with his group of Gandharvas (heavenly musicians) and Apsaras (heavenly dancers) presented their first performance.

subject: ARTS
text: At the time, the great dancer Mahadeva was also in the audience.

subject: ARTS
text: He was so pleased to see the performance that he offered Bharata Muni special lessons with his best ganas (attendants) in the rigorous form of dancing called tandava. Mahadeva’s gana, Tandu_ taught tandava to the sages who taught it to the humans.

subject: ARTS
text: TUS 17S

subject: ARTS
text: ch14_DANCE.indd 154

subject: ARTS
text: On the other hand, Devi Parvati trained Bharata Muni in the more graceful form of dance called lasya.

subject: ARTS
text: 154 | KRITI

subject: ARTS
text: Devi Parvati also taught lasya dance to Usha, the daughter of King Bana. And Usha taught the dance to the gopis (milkmaids) of Dwarka who then taught it to the women of Saurashtra.

subject: ARTS
text: And so, more and more people learnt dance, and that is how dance reached the earth.

subject: ARTS
text: Legends are a rich source for storytelling in the Indian dance forms. Stories from the Puranas, Jataka Tales, Panchatantra, etc., offer narratives that make for beautiful visual spectacles and have a deep moral message.

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
text: NOTE TO THE

subject: ARTS
text: Dear Teacher,

subject: ARTS
text: As our students complete another stage of school education this year, let us add more colours to their academic journey with the learning of visual arts. The chapters in this section would strengthen their knowledge of visual fundamentals while also developing their artistic skills and cultural awareness. You can modify the activities to suit your local context and the specific needs of your students.

subject: ARTS
text: To create the best learning experience for every student, here are some points that need to be kept in mind.

subject: ARTS
text: THE VISUAL ARTS CLASSROOM WOULD REQUIRE

subject: ARTS
text: 1. Adequate space for students to work comfortably. 2. Sufficient light and ventilation.

subject: ARTS
text: 3. Organised storage and easy access to art materials, tools, basic stationery, and audio-visual facilities.

subject: ARTS
text: 4. Space for showcasing and exhibiting artwork periodically.

subject: ARTS
text: VISUAL ARTS PEDAGOGY WOULD NEED TO

subject: ARTS
text: 1. Use storytelling and everyday examples to introduce concepts, and processes.

subject: ARTS
text: = TEACHERS 2. Encourage students to freely express their

subject: ARTS
text: original ideas, imaginations, emotions and

subject: ARTS
text: curiosities in their artwork.

subject: ARTS
text: Motivate students to create original artwork inspired by their observations of everyday life and experiences, rather than copying images from other sources.

subject: ARTS
text: Allow the students to explore, investigate, experiment, collaborate and have dialogues in the classroom.

subject: ARTS
text: Include outdoor activities and field trips to observe the life, and culture around them.

subject: ARTS
text: Organise visits to museums, heritage monuments and melas.

subject: ARTS
text: Invite local artists and craftspersons for interactive sessions, and workshops for hands-on experience.

subject: ARTS
text: Inculcate simple habits of cleaning after working, putting back materials that have been used and maintaining materials with care.

subject: ARTS
text: Encourage the students’ participation and decision-making in selecting artwork for classroom display or exhibitions.

subject: ARTS
text: Visual Arts assessment should be based on the following competencies for the middle stage. C-1.1 Expresses their personal and everyday life experiences confidently through various visual art forms. C-1.2 Demonstrates flexibility in the process of collaboratively developing visual arts practice. C-2.1 Creates visual artwork based on situations or stories that challenge stereotypes observed in their surroundings (such as gender roles) C-2.2 Connects visual imagery, symbols, and visual metaphors with personal experiences, emotions and imaginations

subject: ARTS
text: C-3.1 Demonstrates care and makes informed choices, while using various materials, tools, and techniques in visual arts.

subject: ARTS
text: C-3.2Refinesideas and techniques ofvisual expression from the stage of planning to the final presentation, and reviewing the entire process.

subject: ARTS
text: c-4.1 Demonstrates familiarity with various local and regional forms of art.

subject: ARTS
text: C-4.2 Describes the life and work of a few local artists in their region and across India.

subject: ARTS
text: ELEMENTS AND PRINCIPLES OF VISUAL ART AND DESIGN

subject: ARTS
text: Elements of visual art and design are similar to the ingredients of a recipe. For example, halwa can be prepared by cooking a combination of flour, sugar, ghee and water.

subject: ARTS
text: Point is a dot. It is the smallest element in any visual.

subject: ARTS
text: Line is the visible path that joins any two points. Lines can be horizontal, vertical, diagonal, dashed, wavy, zig-zagged and so on. They can also vary in thickness.

subject: ARTS
text: Shape and form

subject: ARTS
text: A shape is a flat, two- dimensional area enclosed by a line. It can be geometric or organic.

subject: ARTS
text: Lion Capital, Mauryan period, circa 250 BCE

subject: ARTS
text: 0879CHIS

subject: ARTS
text: Similarly, a visual can be made by

subject: ARTS
text: combining elements, such as point, line, shape or form, colour, value, texture and space.

subject: ARTS
text: A form is a_ three- dimensional shape. It occupies space and has depth. Forms can also be created by arranging or joining many two-dimensional shapes.

subject: ARTS
text: Notice the form of the lion in the image. what other forms do you see?

subject: ARTS
text: 4. Texture can be visual and physical. It can be sensed by touching a surface that feels soft, rough, grainy, silky, prickly and so on. It can also be perceived visually through patterns of lines and dots.

subject: ARTS
text: Colour is visible when light is reflected and perceived by our eyes. Colours are either extracted from nature or manufactured

subject: ARTS
text: synthetically to make dyes and pigments.

subject: ARTS
text: Notice the colours in the image, can you guess the natural materials used to create them?

subject: ARTS
text: Value or Tone is the lightness or darkness of a colour. Adding white to a colour makes

subject: ARTS
text: it lighter (tints), whereas adding black to a colour makes it darker (shades). These create colour gradations.

subject: ARTS
text: Observe the colour tonalities in the painting.

subject: ARTS
text: Space is where various elements are organised and composed to create an artwork. Space can be divided into positive and negative space.

subject: ARTS
text: Identify the foreground and background in the painting.

subject: ARTS
text: Shadanga refers

subject: ARTS
text: to the six limbs of an art. This has been codified in the ancient Indian text of Vishnu- dharmottara Purana. This text provides guidance on how to combine the visual elements in an aesthetic or tasteful way, while making an artwork. Just like how food tastes good when the ingredients are combined in the correct proportions and cooked at the right temperature.

subject: ARTS
text: GED = PRINCIPLES OF VISUAL ART AND DESIGN

subject: ARTS
text: Well-composed visuals communicate ideas and emotions effectively because they follow the principles of art and design. Read about each of the principles and connect them with the painting on this page.

subject: ARTS
text: 1. Unity and Harmony are created by bringing elements together in a way that is pleasing to the eye. Observe the combination and distribution of colours used in the painting.

subject: ARTS
text: 2. Balance gives visual stability. For example, if one half of an artwork has a large image, it can be balanced in the other half. Symmetrically, either by a similar and large image or asymmetrically, by many small images. Observe the visual balance in the Tribhanga posture of the mother, and the position of the child.

subject: ARTS
text: 3. Rhythm and Movement guide our eyes from one part to another in an appealing manner. They are created through pattern and repetition.

subject: ARTS
text: Mother and Child, Jamini Roy, Tempera on canvas

subject: ARTS
text: Observe the plant stem next to the mother and other lines on her clothes.

subject: ARTS
text: Emphasis is created by making any one of the visual element stand out. Observe the coloured palm of the mother’s hand, holding the flower.

subject: ARTS
text: Proportion is the relationship between the sizes of different visual elements. It contributes to the beauty, while also expressing the ideas and emotions. Observe the size of the baby in relation to the mother in this painting.

subject: ARTS
text: Hierarchy is the order of importance in a visual. Observe that the mother is given maximum space in the painting. After that, focus on the child, followed by other details of the surroundings.

text: From cave paintings to temple

subject: ARTS
text: sculptures, objects were an [ ©) integral part of artworks, but

subject: ARTS
text: were never the main subject. In

subject: ARTS
text: Indian art, objects were depicted to convey symbolic meanings and were an integral part of the composition. For example, the Dharma Chakra or wheel of law, weapons and musical instruments were held by deities, courtiers, and so on.

subject: ARTS
text: Around the 16th century, a big change took place. Objects became the main subject of artworks. Artists got interested in arranging and studying a variety of natural, and human-made objects which remained still. The skill in painting it was in the manner that not only make it appear three-dimensional but as if life was added to them. This is why such artworks came to be called still life.

subject: ARTS
text: Still life are not restricted only to drawing and painting. Artists create still life compositions as photographs and sculptures too. Today, still life compositions are also used to create product advertisements for magazines, hoardings, newspapers, television, and so on.

subject: ARTS
text: 178 | KRITI

subject: ARTS
text: | ACTIVITY 16.1: ARRANGING A STILL LIFE | 16.1: ARRANGING A STILL LIFE

subject: ARTS
text: Step 2: Choosing the backdrop

subject: ARTS
text: Select one or two large pieces of single-coloured cloth to create a backdrop. The colour ofthe cloth should not distract your attention from the objects, rather complements it. If you do not have cloth, you can use any other material that would create a plain backdrop so that the objects are in focus.

subject: ARTS
text: A FEW OF MY FAVOURITE THINGS

subject: ARTS
text: In a still life, it is very important to have a visually interesting compositional arrangement. This leads our eye to explore every object as we perceive its contour, form, colour, texture and relate it to the other objects placed around it.

subject: ARTS
text: Make small groups according to your shared interests before beginning this activity.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 1: Choosing objects for a still life

subject: ARTS
text: 1. Choose objects from your everyday life and culture, which convey your identity and belonging. You would enjoy making it because you know its minutest details. For example, a basket, clock, ball, toy, shoes, trophies, flowers, fruits, etc.

subject: ARTS
text: 2. Search for rare or unusual objects made by local artists along with other objects that complement it.

subject: ARTS
text: 3. Select three to four objects that are of varying materials, colours, textures, sizes and dimensions.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 3: Arranging the objects

subject: ARTS
text: 1. Drape the cloth with a few folds that fall naturally.

subject: ARTS
text: In each of these artworks, identify the side from

subject: ARTS
text: 2. Place objects so that it appear to overlap a little when seen from different angles. The objects should be composed as one unit.

subject: ARTS
text: 3. Experiment with interesting placements before finalising an arrangement. For example, an object can be placed upright or on its side, or leaning on something or raised, etc.

subject: ARTS
text: 4. Light and shadow: Objects should be placed where light falls on it from one side, and creates tonalities and shadows. For this, you can partially close or open doors and windows in your classroom, or use screens, old banners, curtains or sheets to adjust, or filter the light.

subject: ARTS

text: INTRODUCTION TO PERSPECTIVE

subject: ARTS
text: Paintings and drawings have the power to transport you to other worlds. Some appear two-dimensional and entice you with the beauty of lines, patterns, colours and textures. Some others appear three-dimensional as though they are popping out of the surface. Have you wondered how this happens?

subject: ARTS
text: Perspective is the technique of showing three-dimensional space on a two-dimensional surface. It creates an illusion of distance and depth, where things that are closer, appear bigger and have more details than those that are further away. You can create this magic with practice, by keenly observing the views in front of you.

text: GRD HUMAN ANATOMY

subject: ARTS
text: The structure of the human body is called anatomy. Look at your old photographs and notice how your body structure has changed from the time you were a baby till the present. Over the years, some parts of your body grow more than the others.

subject: ARTS
text: The relationship between the different parts of the body is measured, and expressed in ratio and proportions. For example, if the head is one part, we can find out which parts of the body are of the same size (1:1), which parts are twice the size of the head (1:2) and which parts are thrice the size of the head (1:3).

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
text: The system of measuring the ratio and proportions of the human body has been a central part of Indian painting, and the sculpture traditions. Texts from the Shilpa Shastra mention different ratios and: proportions for depicting divine beings, people of 1 royalty, warriors, children, animals and various | other mythological beings. The system is known as the Talamana Paddhati, where the unit of one tala is 3 equal to the length of an adult hand measured from: the bottom of the wrist to the tip of the middle finger.

subject: ARTS
text: There are small variations in the body proportions of every person, which makes them look different from others. There are no stereotypical proportions that everyone can fit into.

subject: ARTS
text: Observe the body proportions of your own friends and peers, and make drawings from it. Take turns to pose in standing positions so that you can observe and draw the whole body.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 1: Start with the head and note the proportions. You have learnt to use your pencil as a measuring tool while drawing still life objects. In the same way, use your pencil to measure the size of the head and note the number of times it repeats in the body.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 2: Based on the proportions that you have measured, make rough markings so that your drawing of the entire body fits comfortably on your paper.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 3: Continue to measure and verify the proportions as you draw each part. Focus on capturing the proportions that you see.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 4: Complete your drawing and share it with your friends. Take feedback from your teacher on the parts of your drawing that look proportionate and where you can improve.

subject: ARTS
text: After you make one or two drawings of the standing figure, observe the body proportions in different postures and positions, such as sitting, bending, lying, squatting, and other positions. Request your friends or family members to pose for you as you draw them.

subject: ARTS
text: Show them your drawings and tell them the fascinating things you have learnt about the proportions of human body.

subject: ARTS
text: Art is a part of our everyday life. From the clothes we wear to the plate we eat from, all is a piece of art. In this chapter, you will be introduced to a variety of art practices that primarily use everyday materials like thread, paper and cloth to create beautiful objects, and artwork. You will learn how these materials are crafted using specific techniques, and in the process, you will be able to appreciate the hard work, patience and dedication of hundreds of artists, who have kept these traditions alive.

subject: ARTS
text: Nature has fascinating networks that connect all living beings to one another.

subject: ARTS
text: Even though you don’t usually see the roots of plants and trees, you know that they sustain life. Some trees like the banyan have roots that grow out of their branches above the ground.

subject: ARTS
text: In Meghalaya, the Indian rubber tree has very strong secondary roots that grow above the ground. The people of the region have trained these living roots to form long bridges across streams and rivers.

subject: ARTS
text: parts ofour country. Baskets, handloom fabric, fans and even charpoy are created using these techniques. These are everyday objects created for daily use by the people, for the people.

subject: ARTS
text: Find ropes made of cotton, jute or any other natural fibre that is easily available in your region and create a small artwork yourself.

subject: ARTS
text: It takes a lot of time for these bridges to form. They are gently twisted onto one another and tied in different places for support. The bridges get stronger over time as the roots grow.

subject: ARTS

text: Note to the Teacher: Highlight the connection that human societies have with nature and the importance of sustainable choices across art practices.

text: Fabricshavealonglife. Patchworkisatechniqueusedinmany parts of the world, where small pieces of fabric are joined and sewn together to create a large piece offabric. They are madeinto blankets, cradles, bags, cushion covers, table mats, dhurries, and so on. In many parts of India, women bring fragments of old fabric that each of them collect and quilt it together.

subject: ARTS
text: These patchwork quilts are like the symbols of shared memories. Imagine our society as a patchwork quilt. Each individual plays an equally important role in creating the overall picture. Anything one person does or creates has the power to change the picture of their entire society. Patchwork

subject: ARTS
text: Work in small groups for this activity.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 1: Collect old fabric from your homes that are not in use anymore. Go around and check in your school as well.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 2: Find a large piece that is minimum 30 cm x 30 cm to use as your base.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 3: Gather the other pieces you have collected and cut them into squares or rectangles of approximately 5-6 cm.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 4: Spread your base fabric and place the smaller pieces over it in a pattern you find visually interesting.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 5: Join and sew the individual pieces together along their edges on the reverse side. This will ensure that the stitches are not seen when you flip them over.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 6: After joining all the small pieces, place the patchwork on the base cloth and sew it using many lines of running stitches over the patches. You can create interesting patterns and use coloured threads for the lines of running stitches.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 7: Complete your quilt by closing up the edges with another piece of cloth or by folding and stitching.

subject: ARTS
text: Thousands of newspapers are printed daily. They are discarded after reading and are sometimes reused as packaging material, or made into bags, and so on.

subject: ARTS
text: What do you do with old newspapers?

subject: ARTS
text: When certain kinds of soft paper like newspaper and tissue are mixed with water and glue, they become very strong.

subject: ARTS
text: Papier-maché is a_ technique through which this mixture of paper, water and glue are molded into a three-dimensional form.

subject: ARTS
text: These forms are inspired by the artist’s environment and their culture. They are then painted using pigments available in the region. Even though artists use the same

subject: ARTS
text: Kashmiri Papier-maché box base of papier-mdaché, the motifs with dite Chatter tana wnt and patterns vary from region to region.

subject: ARTS
text: Everyday material like paper can be transformed into beautiful artworks. Papier-mdaché is widely practised in many parts of our country. How do you think these practices have travelled from one part of the country to another?

subject: ARTS
text: Note to the Teacher: The process of making paper pulp involves careful observation of the material consistency at every stage. Connect this activity with science concepts, and skills

subject: ARTS
text: to analyse changes in the property of Paper caused by water and glue.

subject: ARTS
text: CH-18_VA.indd 204

subject: ARTS
text: HD LEARN TO MAKE PAPIER-MACHE

subject: ARTS
text: Work in small groups for this activity. Follow this process to create a small form using papier-maché.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 1: Cut old newspapers into small pieces or thin strips and soak them in water for a few days in a large tub or container.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 2: Take out the soaked paper and squeeze out the excess water from it.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 3: Crush, mash or grind the paper into a pulp. You can also use a mortar and pestle to grind it by hand.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 4: Add a little glue to the paper pulp and mix it well.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 5: Take a small bowl or any other shallow object as your mould and coat its outer surface with any greasy substance like petroleum jelly or a thick oil.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 6: Turn the object upside down. Take thin strips of damp newspaper and overlap them over the object evenly till the entire surface is covered. Apply the pulp thickly and evenly over the entire object. Allow it to dry completely for a few days.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 7: When dry, turn the object over and gently release the mould.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 8: Neaten up your papier-maché artwork by using a fine sandpaper, and add colour and decorations to it.

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
